
---
title: China's first local Covid case since February had been vaccinated – state media
categories: 
    - 传统媒体
    - 卫报 The Guardian - China
author: 卫报 The Guardian - China
comments: false
date: Sat, 20 Mar 2021 07:27:08 GMT
thumbnail: https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/dd5c9e4c01e514195b2e72d612d3de38a0441618/0_116_3500_2101/master/3500.jpg?width=300&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=c5a878f2dcab351c9c2bd046f06f045a
---

<div>   
<figure><img alt="A man receives a Covid-19 vaccine in Beijing. China’s first locally transmitted case for weeks had been given the jab." src="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/dd5c9e4c01e514195b2e72d612d3de38a0441618/0_116_3500_2101/master/3500.jpg?width=300&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=c5a878f2dcab351c9c2bd046f06f045a" referrerpolicy="no-referrer"><br><figcaption>A man receives a Covid-19 vaccine in Beijing. China’s first locally transmitted case for weeks had been given the jab.
                        
                            Photograph: Getty Images</figcaption></figure>


                            

                            

                            <p>China’s first local coronavirus case since February was a staff worker at a hospital who had received two shots of a vaccine between end-January and early February, state media has reported.</p> 
<p>The patient, identified by her surname Liu, had been working in the quarantine area of a hospital in Xian city since 4 March, and was mainly responsible for collecting samples from quarantined people for coronavirus testing, the Health Times reported on Saturday.</p> 
 
<p>The Health Times is listed as a newspaper published under The People’s Daily, the official newspaper of China’s ruling Communist Party.</p> 
<p><strong>China</strong> had reported the case on Thursday, making it the country’s first locally transmitted case since 14 February.</p> 
<p>The Health Times, citing a joint expert group of Shaanxi province where Xian city is located, said Liu was infected after being accidentally exposed while in the hospital’s quarantine area.</p> 
<p>The publication quoted Zeng Guang, former chief epidemiologist of China’s disease control and prevention centre, as saying that the protection rate of the vaccine is “not 100%”, and that it is “relatively safe rather than “absolutely safe”, but the public should not doubt domestic vaccines due to this case.</p> 
<p>“The efficacy rate of domestic vaccines in preventing severe cases in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/china" data-link-name="auto-linked-tag" data-component="auto-linked-tag" class="u-underline">China</a> is more than 90%, and the overall protection rate is more than 70%,” said Zeng, adding that coronavirus treatment hospitals are high-risk areas where vaccinated medical staff cannot rule out the possibility of infection.</p> 
<p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/dec/14/chinas-sinopharm-vaccine-how-effective-is-it-and-where-will-it-be-rolled-out" data-link-name="in body link" class="u-underline">China has developed its own vaccines</a> but Zeng did not specify which vaccine Liu had received.</p> 
<p>Thirty-three staff working in the quarantine area with Liu had negative nucleic acid test results, and have undergone centralised medical isolation and observation.</p> 
<p>The news from China came as several European countries resumed vaccinating citizens with the AstraZeneca treatment following an all-clear from European Union regulators and the World Health Organization.</p> 
<p>Worries that AstraZeneca’s Covid-19 vaccine may cause blood clots had seen countries pause its use recently.</p> 
<p>But after the European Medicines Agency said it was “safe and effective”, <strong>Germany</strong> and <strong>Italy</strong> announced they were using the jab again as of Friday.</p> 
<p><strong>France</strong>, where one-third of the population entered a new partial lockdown on Saturday, also brought it back into use on Friday. But just hours later, the national health regulator recommended its use <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/mar/19/france-limits-astrazeneca-covid-jab-to-over-55s-despite-ema-green-light" data-link-name="in body link" class="u-underline">only for over-55s</a>, given the reported blood clots were only seen in younger people.</p> 
<p>World Health Organization vaccine safety experts said “available data do not suggest any overall increase in clotting conditions” among vaccinated people.</p> 
<p>The <strong>Netherlands, Spain, Portugal and Indonesia</strong> were also ending their suspensions, while Ireland’s advisory committee is recommending following suit.</p>

</figure> 
<p>Seeking to reassure their populations, British prime minister Boris Johnson and his French counterpart Jean Castex <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/mar/19/boris-johnson-receives-first-dose-of-oxfordastrazenca-covid-vaccine" data-link-name="in body link" class="u-underline">received their first AstraZeneca dose on Friday</a>.</p> 
<p><strong>Poland</strong> begins a new three-week lockdown on Saturday, with shops, hotels, cultural and sporting facilities closed.</p> 
<p><strong>Ukraine</strong>, which has seen the third biggest rise in new cases in the world this week according to figures compiled by Agence France-Presse, will also impose some restrictions on movements from SAturday. Cases have risen 55% to an average of 11,200 per day this week. <strong>Bangladesh</strong> saw the highest rise with 92% more new cases this week, while <strong>Moldova</strong> was third with 78%.</p> 
<p><strong>India</strong> reported 40,953 new coronavirus cases on Saturday, the biggest daily jump in nearly four months, with its richest state and economic backbone Maharashtra accounting for more than half the infections.</p> 
<p>Deaths rose by 188 to 159,404, the health ministry reported, underscoring a resurgence of the virus in the world’s third worst affected country, after the United States and Brazil.</p> 
<p>Other European countries such as <strong>Italy</strong> and <strong>Spain</strong> have opted for curfews rather than a lockdown in a bid to reduce the rate of transmission.</p> 
<p><strong>Belgium</strong> and <strong>Switzerland</strong>, where cases are also soaring, also put off lifting restrictions on Friday.</p>

                            

                            





                          
</div>
